_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary:
Airgas USA, LLC operates a propane storage/filling facility with 32 employees in Waukesha, WI. The facility is manned 12-20 hours per day. The Waukesha propane process receives product by propane transport truck that is stored onsite a bulk storage vessel (108,000 lbs / 30,000 gallons) before being transferred into gas cylinders then distributed to customers. Cylinders containing between 20 and 100 lbs of propane are filled on a daily basis. Each is weighed after filling, increasing operational safety.

Regulated Chemical:
Propane stored and transferred on site is listed as a highly hazardous chemical under the EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP), and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations. The Airgas Waukesha, WI onsite inventory of propane is in excess of 10,000 pounds making the propane process and its connected equipment a PSM/RMP covered process.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:
The highly flammable and hazardous nature of propane in the process makes it necessary for Airgas to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human and environmental exposure and to reduce the potential threat to personnel and nearby members of the community. Airgas' policy is to comply with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. This Executive Summary sets forth some of the management systems in place to implement the accidental release and prevention program. Airgas has also implemented specific chemical prevention steps to help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors. The following examples of the types of safety features in place: (1) Release Mitigation - Emergency stop buttons to isolate propane sources; personal protective equipment (protective outerwear clothing, intrinsically safe devices, safety glasses, shoes, etc.) (2) System Integrity - Automatic control and manual valves that provides isolation for pr

opane process equipment, check valves on propane delivery lines and pressure safety valves for the process piping and vessels. (3) Facility and Environment - Waukesha, WI plant emergency action plan.

Employee Participation (EP)
Airgas has developed a written plan of action and Waukesha employee/operators are expected to participate in the accidental release prevention program (RMP/PSM). Employees are trained on and provided access to the propane process safety information. Specific actions an employee can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the Employee Participation plan. Forms of participation include being part of a PHA, a PSSR, and/or being involved in incident investigation. Employees participate in monthly safety meetings where process safety issues are discussed and corrective actions are developed, and they are involved in the review of the covered process operating procedures annually to ensure they are current, accurate and recommend any necessary changes.

Process Safety Information (PSI)
Airgas keeps a variety of technical documents onsite and in the company's electronic document control system that are used to help maintain safe operation of its processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, equipment design/configuration information, specific chemical inventories and operation limits for key process parameters - all key information for operating the process safely. Process operators are trained to operate the process using process controls and instrumentation within these safe operating limits. The Safety Coordinator and Facility Managers are responsible for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
Airgas has a risk management program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. The covered process underwent an initial process hazard analysis (PHA) and will continue to undergo periodic revie

w/re-validations at least every five years or as required by Management Of Change (MOC). The PHA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards and mitigating controls of the process and also
represents a cross-section of the employees working in the process. For future PHA reviews, local and corporate management will review the PHA team findings and develop a resolution action plan for each item, which will be documented, tracked and ultimately closed in the Airgas action item database tracking system. Facility Manager is responsible for prioritizing and tracking implementation of the action plan to closure.

Operating Procedures (OP)
Airgas maintains controlled written procedures that address various modes of liquefied and gaseous propane process operations, such as: (1) unit initial startup; (2) unit normal operations; (3) unit emergency shutdown; (4) unit normal shutdown and; (5) unit startup after turnaround or emergency shutdown. Additionally, the emergency shutdown procedure includes conditions that will prompt a shutdown and identifies qualified and responsible operators to complete the steps in a safe and timely manner. Operation under temporary or emergency procedures require and MOC, should the need arise. Airgas operating procedures have safe operating limits identified along with consequences of unsafe deviation. Procedures further provide steps for operators to take that will correct or avoid an unsafe deviation. Airgas procedures are used by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.

Training (TN)
Airgas has implemented a training program for all employee/operators involved in the propane covered process. All employees receive a combination of classroom, computer-based (CBT) and hands-on training that addresses such topics as: general orientation, facility rules and practices, process safety inf

ormation, normal and emergency operating procedures, health and safety consideration, use of safety procedures and equipment, incident investigation and emergency
response. In addition, all operators are required to attend refresher training at least every three years. Training is documented and tracked in a local facility matrix and electronically in the Airgas University training system.

Mechanical Integrity (MI)
Airgas has established mechanical integrity (MI) practices and procedures, based on preventative philosophy, to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief valves and vent systems, controls and interlocks, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5)
applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these written activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. The MI program assists with the verification and suitability of new and existing process equipment and, as well as quality control of spare parts and modifications to existing process equipment.

Management of Change (MOC)
Airgas' management of change (MOC) procedure has established the requirements for ensuring proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved and documented prior to implementation through the use of a management of change process. The MOC procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact, and approving planned deviations from procedure. All MOC's are submitted, reviewed by subjective
matter specialist (such as Engineering, Risk Management, Operations, Health and Safety), approved, tracked and closed using an electronic approval and tracking system. Upon closure, personnel whose assigned job functions are impacted by t

he MOC, are briefed and /or trained in the MOC requirements.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)
Airgas ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR's). PSSR's are intended to ensure safety through confirmation that: (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; (3) PHA's have been performed and recommendations resolved before startup of new plants or processes; (4) MOC requirements have been satisfied for modified facilities; and (5) training has been completed and documented for affected operator/employees.

Compliance Audits (CA)
To help ensure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Airgas conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accidental release prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years. Resolutions to recommendations are documented, tracked and closed. Once the resolutions have been completed, changes are communicated to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the covered process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions. Training and communication is documented.

Incident Investigation (II)
Airgas defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Investigation and reporting procedure. Airgas documents incident and subsequent investigation, follow up actions, and closure in an electronic document control system. The Facility Manager is responsible for maintaining a log and tracking incidents and corrective actions through completion. Results of
findings and corrective actions are shared with employee/operators who could be affecte

d by the findings. Reports are retained for at least five years to be reviewed during future PHA's and revalidations.

Hazardous Work Permit System (HWP)
Airgas has a hazardous work permit system in place to help ensure worker and process safety. This system is comprised of a group of corporate procedures, standards and forms under the life safety program. Procedures in place include: (1) energy control; (2) safe work; (3) hot work; (4) confined space entry. Plant personnel are trained on these safe work practices to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed professionally and safely.

Contractors (CON)
Airgas uses contractors to supplement its own workforce when maintenance activities exceed the capabilities or time available for their own employee/operators. Contractors are made aware of the potential dangers involved with a system covered by PSM/RMP. Procedures are in place to make sure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, and (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, prior to their beginning work. Periodically contractors are evaluated to ensure that both their safety performance and training required for work on the propane system meets Airgas' safety standards.

Five-Year Accident History (AH)
The Waukesha propane filling facility has had no accident resulting in either on or off site effects in the last five (5) years for the covered hydrogen process.

Emergency Response Program Information (ERP)
The Waukesha propane filling facility has developed a written emergency action plan. The plan outlines action to be taken at the plant for handling small releases, and if larger the communication to emergency responders, local response agencies, and outside agency notification procedures in the event of a propane release. The emergency plan provides for the evacuation of Waukesha facility person

nel and visitors. Should an emergency involving the release of propane occur that will have off-site consequences Airgas will contact the Waukesha Fire Department and local support authorities, who will coordinate action for the affected community.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Safety is an inherent part of the culture at Airgas and enhancements in safety and operations are actively discussed and supported. The Waukesha propane fill facility continues to review its processes for possibilities of improvement to the covered propane process, operational methods, and new technology to lower risk.
